Banco Santander S.A. Has $8.50 Million Position in CVS Health Corp (CVS) Bp Plc Cuts Holdings in Boeing Co (BA) April 3rd, 2019 - Comments Off on Bp Plc Cuts Holdings in Boeing Co (BA) - Filed Under - by Latisha Jones Tweet
Bp Plc decreased its holdings in shares of Boeing Co (NYSE:BA) by 20.6% in the 4th quarter, according to its most recent 13F filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC). The fund owned 54,000 shares of the aircraft producer’s stock after selling 14,000 shares during the quarter. Bp Plc’s holdings in Boeing were worth $17,408,000 at the end of the most recent reporting period.
A number of other institutional investors have also made changes to their positions in the business. First Republic Investment Management Inc. increased its position in shares of Boeing by 1.5% in the third quarter. First Republic Investment Management Inc. now owns 283,170 shares of the aircraft producer’s stock worth $105,311,000 after purchasing an additional 4,119 shares during the period. Capital International Inc. CA increased its position in shares of Boeing by 150.8% in the third quarter. Capital International Inc. CA now owns 3,210 shares of the aircraft producer’s stock worth $1,194,000 after purchasing an additional 1,930 shares during the period. Brown Brothers Harriman & Co. increased its position in shares of Boeing by 1.2% in the third quarter. Brown Brothers Harriman & Co. now owns 29,796 shares of the aircraft producer’s stock worth $11,081,000 after purchasing an additional 364 shares during the period. Veritable L.P. increased its position in shares of Boeing by 1.3% in the third quarter. Veritable L.P. now owns 21,444 shares of the aircraft producer’s stock worth $7,975,000 after purchasing an additional 265 shares during the period. Finally, Nachman Norwood & Parrott Inc bought a new position in shares of Boeing in the fourth quarter worth $2,164,000. 69.77% of the stock is owned by institutional investors and hedge funds. Get Boeing alerts:
A number of research analysts recently commented on BA shares. Jefferies Financial Group raised their price target on Boeing to $448.00 and gave the stock a “buy” rating in a research report on Monday, February 4th. UBS Group restated a “buy” rating on shares of Boeing in a research report on Wednesday, January 9th. ValuEngine upgraded Boeing from a “hold” rating to a “buy” rating in a research report on Wednesday, January 2nd. Credit Suisse Group restated a “buy” rating and issued a $456.00 price target on shares of Boeing in a research report on Tuesday, December 18th. Finally, Cowen restated a “buy” rating and issued a $445.00 price target on shares of Boeing in a research report on Tuesday, December 18th. Three equities research analysts have rated the stock with a sell rating, eight have given a hold rating and seventeen have given a buy rating to the company. Boeing presently has an average rating of “Buy” and a consensus target price of $405.91. Boeing stock opened at $390.75 on Wednesday. Boeing Co has a 12-month low of $292.47 and a 12-month high of $446.01. The company has a current ratio of 1.08, a quick ratio of 0.31 and a debt-to-equity ratio of 25.99. The stock has a market capitalization of $215.30 billion, a price-to-earnings ratio of 24.41, a price-to-earnings-growth ratio of 1.46 and a beta of 1.34.
Boeing (NYSE:BA) last released its earnings results on Wednesday, January 30th. The aircraft producer reported $5.48 earnings per share (EPS) for the quarter, beating the Zacks’ consensus estimate of $4.52 by $0.96. Boeing had a negative return on equity of 4,286.60% and a net margin of 10.34%. The firm had revenue of $28.34 billion for the quarter, compared to analysts’ expectations of $26.76 billion. During the same quarter in the previous year, the business posted $3.04 earnings per share. The business’s revenue for the quarter was up 14.4% on a year-over-year basis. As a group, equities analysts anticipate that Boeing Co will post 20.11 earnings per share for the current fiscal year.
Boeing announced that its board has authorized a stock buyback program on Monday, December 17th that permits the company to buyback $20.00 billion in outstanding shares. This buyback authorization permits the aircraft producer to repurchase up to 11.1% of its stock through open market purchases. Stock buyback programs are usually an indication that the company’s management believes its stock is undervalued.
In other news, EVP J Michael Luttig sold 8,500 shares of the business’s stock in a transaction dated Tuesday, February 12th. The stock was sold at an average price of $410.46, for a total transaction of $3,488,910.00. The transaction was disclosed in a legal filing with the SEC, which is available through the SEC website . Also, SVP Heidi B. Capozzi sold 2,916 shares of the business’s stock in a transaction dated Wednesday, February 13th. The stock was sold at an average price of $410.84, for a total value of $1,198,009.44. The disclosure for this sale can be found here . In the last quarter, insiders sold 72,247 shares of company stock worth $28,922,977. Company insiders own 0.23% of the company’s stock.
Boeing Company Profile
The Boeing Company, together with its subsidiaries, designs, develops, manufactures, sales, services, and supports commercial jetliners, military aircraft, satellites, missile defense, human space flight and launch systems, and services worldwide. The company operates in four segments: Commercial Airplanes; Defense, Space & Security; Global Services; and Boeing Capital. column1: The Latest: EU official: Tough Brexit’nearly Inescapable’
column8:
10:50 p.m. Get alerts:
Even the European Parliament’s top Brexit official says the U.K. has a”last opportunity” to break the deadlock on leaving the European Union.
Guy Verhofstadt tweeted that the comments soon after alternative choices were again resisted by the Parliament of Britain to the Brexit deal of Prime Minister Theresa May. Parliament has carved out time Wednesday on Brexit alternatives for a second set of suggestive votes. A tough #Brexit gets nearly inevitable. On Wednesday, the U.K. includes a last opportunity to break the deadlock or face the abyss.”
Britain is lawfully expected to leave the EU after the bloc agreed to extend the March 29 deadline.
___
10:20 p.m.
U.K. Conservative Party legislator Nick Boles says he’s stopping the party after one of the Brexit hints was voted down.
Boles made the announcement that was dramatic in Parliament minutes after the results of the votes were first declared, stating he couldn’t remain in the party. 282-261 narrowly defeated it.
Boles said that”I have failed chiefly because my party refuses to compromise.” He said he regretted he could no longer be part of this celebration.
The Conservative Party led by Prime Minister Theresa May is split between those who favor a Brexit with few ties to the EU and people looking for a divorce bargain that was softer.
___
10:15 p.m.
British government claims it’ll continue to pursue assistance for Prime Minister Theresa May’s Brexit bargain.
Brexit Secretary Stephen Barclay says that May’s bargain is the way forward in light of Parliament’s inability to discover a majority for an alternate arrangement. The deal of may is already rejected twice.
Barclay claims the default position requires Britain to leave the European Union at 11 days. He says if Parliament agrees to May’s con agreement this week it”may be possible” to depart the EU without participating in European elections in late May.
He states that the Cabinet will meet Tuesday to discuss choices.
___
10:10 p.m.
British lawmakers have failed to find a majority for any proposal in votes on alternatives to the refused Brexit deal of the government.
Lawmakers rejected four options from the House of Commons in votes.
The votes were an attempt to forge an alternative to the government’s rejected European Union divorce deal.
The choices included remaining in a customs union with the EU — which failed by just three votes — and holding a fresh referendum.
The government is hoping to assemble support for the Brexit agreement, that has been rejected three times from Parliament of Prime Minister Theresa May.
Britain is scheduled to depart the EU on April 12 unless it moves a divorce deal or enrolls an expansion from the bloc.
___
8 p.m.
Lawmakers have started voting on four alternatives to the government Brexit deal.
Rather than the typical process of voting for their feet by walking through”aye” and”no” lobbies, members of Parliament are each receiving a paper ballot list all four choices.
Legislators have an hour to vote until ballots are counted and collected. Results are expected around 2100 GMT (5 pm EDT).
The choices include staying with the EU and holding a referendum.
___
5:20 p.m.
Lawmakers are considering four alternatives to Prime Minister Theresa May Brexit deal, in hopes of finding.
Two suggestions that aim to keep economic ties between Britain and the European Union are for votes night in Parliament included by the choices. One would keep the U.K. at a customs union for goods with the EU later Brexit, while the other calls for Britain to stay in the bloc’s sole market for both products and services.
Another alternative needs any Brexit price to be submitted to a referendum, and also the fourth says Britain should cancel its departure from the EU if it comes within two weeks of crashing without an agreement out of the bloc.
The options were chosen by house of Commons Speaker John Bercow from eight thoughts.
___
2:55 p.m.
A major credit ratings agency has resisted the array of problems it foresees Britain encountering if the country crashes out of the European Union.
Standard & Poor’s stated in an update Monday a disorderly Brexit could”adversely impact income levels and growth prospects, in addition to government finances.”
S&P additionally has been warning that Britain’s withdrawal may”significantly restrict” access to key European economies. The ratings agency says if that comes to pass, it might anticipate”downward pressure” on home prices, a significant increase in the country’s debt and a further drop in the value of the pound.
S&P has stated such a situation could lead it to downgrade Britain’s AA credit rating.
Parliament has hunted down the deal three times of May.
Britain was given by the EU before April 12 to come up with a strategy or to render the bloc.
It’s uncertain if any option that might win approval in the House of Commons would be accepted by May.
___
1:25 p.m.
The chief executive of industrial maker Siemens U.K. is imploring British lawmakers to combine with a undermine Brexit deal, saying the nation’s political chaos will be making the U.K. a”laughing stock.”
Parliament is set to vote Monday on choices to the Union withdrawal deal.
Siemens U.K. CEO Juergen Maier urged lawmakers in an open letter to pick an option that keeps Britain in a customs union with the EU. He said that choice will enable frictionless trade to continue between the U.K. and also the EU, something many companies have started to rely upon.
Maier also wrote that Britain’s political paralysis is”making it tough to acquire support for finely balanced investment choices that in the end have a direct impact on U.K. projects, innovation and the legitimacy of our actions here.”
May’s spokesman, James Slack, says the prime minister knows that”company wants certainty.” He said May’s Brexit deal, which the House of Commons has rejected three times should be supported by lawmakers.
___
1 p.m.
The thoughts of the European Union’s executive will be stressing if it stays an EU member beyond April 12, that Britain will need to participate in the European Parliament elections of May.
Come up with an alternate strategy, which — unless it decides to revoke Brexit — is most very likely to entail regretting its withdrawal or britain either has to leave the EU on April 12.
A few British politicians have suggested the U.K. could remain for more without engaging in the EU elections. However, European Commission chief Jean-Claude Juncker told reporters at Saarbruecken, Germany who”if the British have not left April 12 and there’s an extension, then Britain has to participate in the European elections “
He added”that is (in) the treaty. Whether I need that’s another matter.”
___
12:35 p.m.
European Commission leader Jean-Claude Juncker says it’s time to get the British Parliament to spell out what it wants on Brexit — and says that the mythical sphinx is easier to decode than U.K. lawmakers.
Juncker said in a speech Monday to the Saarland state legislature in Saarbruecken, Germany:”We now know what the British Parliament doesn’t desire, but we have not heard exactly what it needs.
He added:”We should find the sphinx to speak now. Enough of this very long silence.”
__
11:40 a.m.
Discount airline easyJet has warned that the U.K.’s impending withdrawal from the European Union is very likely to hurt earnings in the next half of its fiscal year as travelers hold back on booking tickets amid the impasse over future connections.
EasyJet says its very first half loss of 275 million pounds ($360 million) was in expectations, but also the prognosis for the six months during September will be”more careful” due to”softness in ticket yields from the U.K. and across Europe.”
Shares fell 8.3% in early London trading following the profit warning. Shares in other airlines and travel firms also fell, with British Airways owner IAG down two per cent and travel group TUI down 2.5 percent.
___
10:30 a.m.
Evidence has emerged that British manufacturers are building their cushions against the possibility that the country crashes with no deal from the European Union.
Financial information company IHS Markit discovered that Brexit stockpiling is providing a boost to manufacturing — at least briefly.
According to the firm, its purchasing managers index for the industry rose into a 13-month high in March to 55.1, up three points from the previous month. Anything above 50 indicates an expansion in output.
Stockpiling has become more and more prevalent over the past couple of months as Britain’s exit looms — originally scheduled for March 29 but delayed to April 12.
Given the uncertainty, firms have saved up on those products and about raw materials they require from everywhere in the EU.
___
8:45 a.m.
The chief disciplinarian of prime Minister Theresa May says the authorities ought to have told people they’d need to take a milder form of exiting the European Union later her majority was dropped by May in the 2017 election.
Monday, chief Whip Julian Smith, whose occupation would be to ensure Conservative Party lawmakers vote to the authorities, which makes the remarks to be broadcast.
Smith says May known as the election in bringing Brexit to fortify her hand, but was weakened when she lost her bulk. He says the authorities”should have just been clearer the results of the, the arithmetic, would mean this could be inevitably a kind of softer type of Brexit.”
The remarks come after Parliament refused May’s EU withdrawal bargain on Friday for a period.
___
Follow AP’s full coverage of Brexit at: https://www.apnews.com/Brexit Latest News

column1: Trump suffers Reverses in rulings in Alaska
column8:
Banco Santander S.A. Has $8.50 Million Position in CVS Health Corp (CVS) Trump suffers Reverses in rulings in Alaska April 3rd, 2019 - Comments Off on Trump suffers Reverses in rulings in Alaska - Filed Under - by Stacy Sanders Tweet
In attempting to reverse environmental policies put for Alaska by President Barack Obama the Trump government has suffered a pair of setbacks.
U.S. District Court Judge Sharon Gleason on Friday reported the Trump government violated federal law with a planned road through a national wildlife refuge. Get alerts:
Months after, Gleason ruled that Trump exceeded his authority when he reversed a ban in the majority of the Arctic Ocean and parts of the Atlantic. Earthjustice attorney Erik Grafe (GRAF-ee), who worked on the drilling case, says President Trump’s illegal actions are catching up to him.
Alaska U.S. Sen. Lisa Murkowski, a Republican, says the drilling decision might have catastrophic impacts for overseas well growth, which creates jobs, generates revenue and reinforces national security. Latest News

Kubota (OTCMKTS:KUBTY) was upgraded by Zacks Investment Research from a “sell” rating to a “hold” rating in a report issued on Wednesday, Zacks.com reports.
According to Zacks, “Kubota is the world’s largest maker of small tractors and Japan’s 2nd largest manufacturer of farm equipment. The company is also Japan’s largest producer of ductile iron pipe (for water supply and sewer systems) and its maker of roofing materials. Kubota Company Profile
Kubota Corporation manufactures and sells a range of machinery, and other industrial and consumer products in Japan, North America, Europe, Asia, and internationally. Its Farm & Industrial Machinery segment provides tractors, power tillers, combine harvesters, rice transplanters, lawn mowers, utility vehicles, other agricultural machinery, implements, attachments, post-harvest machinery, vegetable production equipment, and other agricultural equipment; cooperative drying, rice seedling, and gardening facilities; and rice mill plants.

column1: Michael Medved: Message to Congress: Legislate, Don’t Investigate
column8:
Posted by: THAdmin in Commentary , Home Page April 3, 2019 0 112 Views
To the intense disappointment of hyper-partisan Democrats, the Mueller Report delivered anti-climactic results: no evidence of Russian collusion and no new charges against Trump and his team.
Despite his complaints on Twitter and elsewhere, the president allowed Mueller to complete his investigative work without significant interference, so it’s time to put to rest the charges and counter-charges.
Democrats, however, intend to use Congressional Committees to continue investigating Trump’s personal and business history, and some Republicans talk of retaliatory investigations of Obama’s FBI and Justice Department. This waste of taxpayer money is not their primary job as lawmakers: we hire legislators to legislate, not investigate.
Those who want to drive Trump from the White House have only one way to do it: vote him out.
The desperation of Democrats to continue their scandal-mongering only displays their growing fear of crushing defeat in 2020.

column1: It Is Outrageous that Supporting Trump Is Dangerous
column8: No surprise. ProFa, and other pro-fascist actors like the Purple-shirts of the SEIU believe in violence and are anti-First Amendment. The ends justify the means. In 2019, define anything you don't agree with "hate", and you get a green light to pretend to fight fascism, while acting like a Brown-shirt in reality.

column1: It Is Outrageous that Supporting Trump Is Dangerous
column8: Those who would trade freedom for security will have neither freedom nor security.

column1: It Is Outrageous that Supporting Trump Is Dangerous
column8: As much as I hate to admit it, we’re doomed. If the Harridan would have weaseled her way into the White House we’d be there now. Trump just slowed down the inevitable and short of a civil war, which I don’t think enough Americans have the stomach for, it’s over for us. Millennials and generations to come haven’t a clue about this country and what made it great nor do they care and asking them to fight for it would be a waste of time. Our education system made sure of that. Brainwashing kids is all part of the grand plan and it’s working just as Saul Alinsky envisioned. The media, schools, churches, banks, corporations, local and state governments have gone so far left I just can’t see how a turnaround is even possible. I just hate it for my grandchildren. Sad.

column1: It Is Outrageous that Supporting Trump Is Dangerous
column8: We are not doomed, but we will have to fight. That I do believe. I mean, really fight, like with bullets.

column8: Where is Gen. Buck Turgeson when you really need him? Who will lead the charge?

column1: Spains civilian coast guard caught in election crosshairs POLITICO
column8:
Zach Campbell
Beyond that, Furió says he is concerned that one ship won’t be able to cover the section of coast that had, last summer, been covered by four — and even then, he said, crews are overstretched. “They won’t be prepared,” he said. “They don’t have the means. You can’t get people out of the water like that.” Hard to starboard
Members of Salvamento Marítimo were until recently considered folk heroes by the Spanish press. As a growing number of migrants attempted to reach Spain from North Africa — last year saw a record 60,000 people attempt the journey by sea from Morocco to Spain — the rescue service saved thousands of lives in the Strait of Gibraltar and Sea of Alborán.
The first sign of change at the agency came just after a regional election in Andalucía in December, when the far-right Vox party stunned the Spanish establishment by taking an unprecedented 11 percent of the vote on a platform centered around restricting migration. Migrants keep warm in Red Cross blankets after arriving at Malaga's harbor | Jorge Guerrero/AFP via Getty Images
Until then, the country had taken a softer approach to migration than its European neighbors. When Italy’s Deputy Prime Minister, Matteo Salvini, closed Italy’s ports to NGO rescue ships in June 2018, it was Sánchez who stepped into the breach and allowed the vessel to disembark the 629 people on board in Spain .
Since the election, however, the Spanish migration debate has swerved to the right. Politicians and critics in the media frequently describe Salvamento Marítimo as a “taxi service” for migrants trying to reach Spain.
Earlier this year, the Spanish government banned two NGO rescue ships — Open Arms and Aita Mari — from engaging in rescues off the coast of Libya. Both have been unable to leave port for months.
Until Vox’s surprise showing, Salvamento Marítimo’s social media accounts were well-known in Spanish NGO circles for publishing information, sometimes even photos, of every rescue the agency engaged in.
Then, in early December, the accounts stopped publishing arrival information related to sea rescues on the southern border. NGOs and the Spanish press called it an “ information blackout .” Salvamento Marítimo’s press office told journalists at the time that the agency had a “revised communication strategy.”
“There has been a change of direction in the Spanish government’s humanitarian policy,” said Iñigo Barandiaran, a Basque nationalist MP and former spokesperson for the public works committee — which oversees the civilian coast guard — in the Spanish parliament. New ‘operational philosophy’
The Guardia Civil has opened up a “ unitary command ” coordinating all actors working on irregular migration through Spain’s southern sea border. The command includes representatives from Frontex, the EU border and coast guard, Spanish military, intelligence and police, as well as Salvamento Marítimo and the Red Cross, among others.
In a closed-door meeting with NGOs at the Merchant Marina offices on March 13, Salvamento Marítimo’s then-director, Ignacio López — who resigned from the post a week later to run in regional elections — said “the operational philosophy in the southern border has changed,” according to three people in the room, who spoke to POLITICO on the condition of anonymity.
López and the director of the Spanish merchant marina, Benito Núñez, told the group that the strategy would prioritize Morocco’s role in rescues. Moroccan sailors, they explained, will receive training and equipment from Spain and the European Union.
Pressed by representatives of the NGOs on whether Spanish ships would return migrants to Moroccan ports, López acknowledge that the two countries do not have a treaty that would allow that. But he said creating one would be possible, if Morocco agreed. In that case, he said, “it wouldn’t be a return; it would be a rescue,” according to those who attended the meeting. Migrants from Morocco are transferred to a coast guard boat at Algeciras harbour | Jorge Guerrero/AFP via Getty Images
In the meeting, both officials also confirmed plans to use the Clara Campoamor as a “mothership” to which small vessels would transfer rescued people. When that ship is full, it would go to a port to be decided by the Guardia Civil’s unitary command, a spokesperson for the interior ministry later confirmed.
When asked for comment, a spokesperson for the interior ministry declined to clarify whether or not the government was planning to strike an agreement with Morocco to return migrants rescued at sea to the country. López declined to comment for this article; Núñez did not respond to requests.
A spokesperson for Salvamento Marítimo confirmed that the Guardia Civil’s unitary command will be in charge on issues of irregular immigration and said that the agency “moves its assets to adjust its rescue capacity to the current situation,” but declined to take further questions.
At the same time, Spanish and European border authorities are bracing for another surge in arrivals as the weather warms. A spokesperson for Frontex said the agency is expecting increased arrivals from Morocco to Spain.
In a March report by the Spanish Department of National Security, Cabinet advisers noted that, in 2018, Spain registered the highest number of irregular immigrants to the country in recent history.
“We are working to reverse this growing trend, which started three years ago and has accelerated in the last two,” the advisers wrote. “All signs point to, in 2019, the numbers being higher.”
Zach Campbell is a journalist based in Barcelona, Spain. He tweets at @notzachcampbell. Related stories on these topics:

SPDR S&P 500 ETF Trust (the Trust) is a unit investment trust. The Trust seeks to provide investment results that, before expenses, correspond generally to the price and yield performance of the S&P 500 Index (the Index). The Trust seeks to achieve this investment objective by holding a portfolio of the common stocks that are included in the Index (the Portfolio), with the weight of each stock in the Portfolio substantially corresponding to the weight of such stock in the Index.

column1: Botswana says regional bridge row with Zambia has been resolved Political Analysis South Africa
column8:
Botswana says regional bridge row with Zambia has been resolved
Published on Tweet Botswana’s Minister of Transport and Communications Dorcas Makgato has allayed fears that her country and neighbouring Zambia were headed for a diplomatic row.
The issue is over the suspension of construction of a bridge that links the two neighbouring countries and the region.
In a statement, Makgato said the adversity which recently affected the Kazungula Bridge Development has been resolved, and further stated that the project is expected to be completed in 2020. Loading...
“It is a fact that the Contractor–Daewoo International, recently issued a contractually-enforceable notice to suspend works on the bridge project. This was as a result of delayed or non-payment of amounts due from the Employer who, in this case, is a joint and 50/50 partnership between the governments of Botswana and Zambia,” she said.
Makgato said Zambia, which was yet to contribute its share of funds for the construction of the bridge, has moved swiftly to correct by paying all the arrears, and obtaining the Contractor’s agreement and lifting the prevailing suspension of construction of the project.
“As part of resolving the problem, a required minimum amount of US Dollars 16.62m, which has hitherto been overdue is in the process of being transmitted to the Contractor (Daewoo International),” said Makgato.
She added that “The Botswana is pleased with the cooperation, which has been received from both the Zambian and the Contractor in expeditiously and amicably dispensing of the risk, which the project has been facing.”
Makgato concluded that because of its strategic importance to the Southern African Development Community (SADC) Region, and wider trade-facilitation across Africa and beyond, both Botswana and Zambia recognize and wish to reiterate their mutual commitment to having the Kazungula Bridge Project completed soonest and most cost-effectively.
– APA

column1: The Baloney of 'Unchecked Nationalism'
column8: Doesn’t change a thing! You’re still stupid!

column1: The Baloney of 'Unchecked Nationalism'
column8: Much better.

column1: The Baloney of 'Unchecked Nationalism'
column8: I dunno. In hindsight, and with the disastrous gifting to Stalin of even Poland-the western cause of WWII entry; the whole thing looks like a genocidal western civil war. The question needs answered. Who ultimately benefits?

column1: The Baloney of 'Unchecked Nationalism'
column8:
DeplorableMe, you have just summarized the main problems of the two major political parties. Both parties want illegal aliens but for different reasons.
The Republicans want to please their campaign donor
corporations, and the Democrats want more voters even if they are not supposed to vote in American elections. The Democrats also want the campaign money from the corporations. Yep, it's a race to see which party can sell the American people up the creek first.
Now for the grim forecast. When, not if, the general upheaval arrives, ALL of the ruling elite will rue the day they were born. The American workers, who have born the burden of bigger and bigger government, will be in no mood to grant clemency to the very "leaders" who brought about the coming economic collapse caused by a worthless American dollar.
So, we are witnessing the elite having a great ongoing party at the expense of the taxpayers. When this particular party comes crashing down, the politicians who created the whole mess, will be running for their lives. There will be no joy in political Mudville.

column1: The Baloney of 'Unchecked Nationalism'
column8: They didn't foresee a communist new world order. They thought they'd be in charge.

column1: The Baloney of 'Unchecked Nationalism'
column8:
Let us then balkanize. California/the American Soutwest is standing by to be overrun with foreign nationals. The Northeast is populated by people whose ideas and politics are something the people in the Southeast and Midwest have no understanding or tolerance for, nor will they ever. The problem is that once, say, East TN becomes it's own self-governed region of mostly white, hard working God fearing people it will become, more than likely, the richest, most peaceful and prosperous region on earth. Then what will happen is that the people in dire straits in the cess pools of the West and Northeast will see this and start trying to migrate to this beautiful place with peace and a beautiful homogenous population. Therefore the balkanization will end, and the region will be trampled with crazed liberal losers.
Well, crap, I just unintentionally gave a history lesson instead of a glimpse of a hopeful, balkanized future.

column1: The Baloney of 'Unchecked Nationalism'
column8: They are doing that right now liberals are moving to the south in droves and then voting for politicians with policies that created the hell holes they just escaped from.

column1: The Baloney of 'Unchecked Nationalism'
column8: It's the same here. Beautiful farmlands, meadows and forests being destroyed to give subdivisions to refugees from the liberal loony bins. Then they vote in like minded people who in turn run things like their former homes. Sad, but nothing's to be done.

column1: The Baloney of 'Unchecked Nationalism'
column8: Not sure I completely get your point but I would offer that many many political decisions are made from the expeditious short term view of what seems to cause the least danger in the short term. As Yogi famously said "predictions are hard, especially about the future." And sometimes you have to stand your ground.

Hudson Technologies (NASDAQ:HDSN) was downgraded by Zacks Investment Research from a “hold” rating to a “sell” rating in a note issued to investors on Monday, Zacks.com reports.
According to Zacks, “Hudson Technologies, Inc. is a leading provider of innovative solutions to recurring problems within the refrigeration industry. Hudson’s proprietary RefrigerantSide Services increase operating efficiency and energy savings, and remove moisture, oils and other contaminants frequently found in the refrigeration circuits of large comfort cooling and process refrigeration systems. Performed at a customer’s site as an integral part of an effective scheduled maintenance program or in response to emergencies, RefrigerantSide Services offer significant savings to customers due to their ability to be completed rapidly and at higher purity levels, and can be utilized while the customer’s system continues to operate. In addition, the Company sells refrigerants and provides traditional reclamation services to the commercial and industrial air conditioning and refrigeration markets. “ Get Hudson Technologies alerts:

column1: The Wise Purpose of the Electoral College
column8:
Does the Electoral College more or less protect the Conservatives more than the Liberals? Just when I think I’m understanding it, I really don’t. Except for the fact that yes, those big bad cities do tend to wipe out the votes in some of the other states.
So the advantage is... the State that votes Conservative won’t have to be ruled by the Left, since their vote got diluted. Maybe I get it after all?
Just wish somebody could clarify the details (numbers) more.
“MAGA!”

column1: The Wise Purpose of the Electoral College
column8: Representatives are selected by each state according to the population of the state. The popular vote determines the number of representatives, thus a state like Florida has 16 electoral votes that are eventually number of people who go to the electoral voting place, What controls who votes democrat, republican, independent etc is the number of total votes that can be divided up sometimes. But the other thing is that the representatives can vote their own way if they want and some have done so. Usually this does not go over well with the people they represent and the vote can be challenged, but up to this point, the electoral college reps have been awesomely dedicated to voting the way the electorate of their state voted. When the call states for a Presidential nominee it means that enough votes went a certain way for the state to claim all 16 votes for the winner of the popular vote in their state.

column1: The Wise Purpose of the Electoral College
column8:
Actually I just thought of the perfect answer to the Electoral ‘problem.’ Socialism!
“MAGA!”

column1: The Wise Purpose of the Electoral College
column8: While doing my own personal Bible study years ago, I got the impression that it was the cities that were where evil seemed to congregate. The reason most rural areas vote Republican, and the reason (I think) that Trump won Florida? And probably other states too.

column1: The Wise Purpose of the Electoral College
column8: Oh you noticed too? Started with BO I think. The cool guy. The traitor.

column1: The Wise Purpose of the Electoral College
column8: To some degree it's already happening. Big-city Progressives are moving to lower-tax states, and bringing their politics with them. It's happening on a smaller scale in the generally conservative county we moved to 30 years ago. The city people have been moving out for personal benefit (taxes, cheaper housing, traffic, better schools) and they are bring their $hit with them. Now it's not unusual to be tailgated, flipped off, every tax/bond issue passed, tiny yards, crime, etc.

column1: The Wise Purpose of the Electoral College
column8: national popular vote compact is unconstitutional because it violates the First Amendment, an Article 1 Section 10 Clause 3.

column1: The Wise Purpose of the Electoral College
column8: Sorry, that doesn't fly, because equal suffrage in the Senate was maintained both before and after the 17th.

column1: The Wise Purpose of the Electoral College
column8: What is interesting is that the equal suffrage requirement is the only thing in the Constitution that is not subject to the amendment process, per Article V. There was one other but it expired in the early 1800s In other words, it's locked in. You almost have to throw out the entire Constitution to get rid of it. Which is, of course, the left's intent.

column1: US stocks post on encouraging Information, End
column8:
Owens & Minor (OMI) Stock Rating Upgraded by ValuEngine US stocks post on encouraging Information, End April 3rd, 2019 - Comments Off on US stocks post on encouraging Information, End - Filed Under - by Tyrone Williams Tweet
Stocks closed higher on Wall Street Monday following a heap of encouraging international financial statistics kept investors in a buying mood.
Financial and technology companies powered a lot of this rally, which prolonged the gains of the market from last week, even once the 500 closed its best quarter in nearly a decade out. Get alerts:
In another hopeful sign bond yields climbed after a sharp drop last month that flashed rattling Wall Street, a potential recession warning. These concerns were allayed Monday as new economic data suggested a wider outlook for the U.S. market. An indicator of U.S. manufacturing instills a significant gain in March, though a different report showed construction spending climbed in February. An economic report from China showed growth in orders, employment and exports.
Even though the data that was reassuring gave a boost to stocks, the marketplace could face some bumps ahead, said Liz Ann Sonders, chief investment strategist at Charles Schwab.
“The barrier in the near-term is still going to be earnings,” she explained. “That’s the next important stage.”
Even the S&P 500 gained 32.79 points, or 1.2%, to 2,867.19, notching a three-day winning streak.
The Nasdaq composite climbed 99.59 points, or 1.3%, to 7,828.91. The Russell 2000 index of smaller company stocks selected up 16.33 points, for a 1.1% gain, to 1,556.06.
European stock indexes finished broadly higher.
Monday’s profits followed a solid conclusion to the first quarter to get U.S. stocks. Even the S&P 500 index is currently up 14.4percent this calendar year, a large turnaround after the index skidded 14 percentage in the final quarter of 2018.
Tech companies and financial powered the rally. When they’re confident that the economy will continue growing, investors have a tendency to prefer those businesses.
Utility businesses and consumer product makers, which are thought of as safe-play investments, lagged the marketplace. Clorox dropped 1.2% and NRG Energy slid 1.7%.
Bond yields continued rising in another sign that investors are confident in the growth of the economy. That came as a welcome relief after a sharp drop in bond yields to their lowest levels in more than annually.
The return in the 10-year Treasury note rose sharply, to 2.50% from 2.41% late Friday. In addition, it rose back above the yield on the Treasury bill.
The change reverses an”inversion” in bond yields that alerted investors last month since such a happening, as it persists over the years, has preceded recessions before.
Essential bond yields dropped to their lowest levels in over annually on March 22 and continued to slip much of last week after the Federal Reserve said it was seeing growth in the economy and expected to boost interest rates this season.
“You seem to the bond market to be a little more cynical and a little before the equity market to where things are going,” said Tom Martin, senior portfolio manager using Globalt Investments. “Therefore, the motion upward in the 10 year (yield) is a rebound that says’OK, we understand there are these problems of a slowdown, but it is not a disaster.'”
The increase in bond returns helped increase bank stocks. Bond yields imply that banks may gain from higher rates of interest on loans.
As traders recognized a solid earnings report by the businesses of the casino operator in Macau and optimistic economic data from China, wynn Resorts led all stocks. The inventory jumped 8.4 percent.
The firm has lost money but has since published growth.
Its IPO was regarded as a harbinger for additional offerings in fast paced firms such as Pinterest Uber and Slack.
Kellogg dropped 2.4percent on news the packaged foods company is selling its Keebler cookie brand and other sweet snacks companies to Ferrero, a Italian supermarket firm best known for making Nutella, for $1.3 billion.
Investors will soon probably likely be focusing on earnings this past month, next week as the next major wave of business results dive right into gear.
Wall Street expects a contraction in earnings during the first quarter. Any firm commentary about their prospects for the next few quarters will be important in providing investors and analysts a better picture of the economy.
Traders have their eye over the U.S.-Chinese trade negotiations, that are due to resume this week. Officials from the world’s two biggest economies are aiming to put to rest a dispute over technology and other issues.
Energy futures closed higher. Benchmark U.S. crude gained 2.4% to settle at $61.59 a barrel. Brent crude, used to cost international monies, closed 2.1% greater at $69.01 per barrel.
Wholesale gas added 0.9percent to $1.90 per gallon, heating oil picked up 0.8percent to $1.99 per gallon and natural gas climbed 1.7% to $2.71 per 1,000 cubic feet.
Gold inched 0.3% reduced to $1,294.20 a ounce, silver dropped 0.1% to $15.10 an ounce and copper dropped 0.4percent to $2.92 per pound. Latest News
